Reuters Canada's telecom spending not yet bottomed, study Monday February 10, 4:19 pm ET By Susan Taylor
OTTAWA, Feb 10 (Reuters) - A spending chill that has gripped Canada's phone companies shows no signs of thawing, or hitting bottom, according to an IDC Canada study released on Monday that has a bleak outlook for 2003.
The research group said that after a dreadful 2002, when Canada's telecommunication service providers cut equipment purchases by 46 percent, 2003 won't be any better.
The study said initial budget forecasts from Canada's major phone companies show a further 19 percent drop to C$5.8 billion ($3.8 billion) in spending. It's a far cry from the budgets that peaked at C$13.5 billion in 2001.
But IDC Canada also provided a glimmer of hope, with a forecast that spending may thaw in 2004.
"Any further reductions in the capex for them will be more fine-tuning," said Lawrence Surtees, IDC director of telecom and Internet research.
"I can see 2004 (having) a little bit of a drop, but then stabilizing as most of these guys reach the targets of what they want the ratio between revenue and capital spending to be."
Surtees said Canada's recovery will likely lag that of the U.S., which is expected to plateau at the end of 2003.
While that prediction is at odds with industry players who suggest the worst has passed, all segments of Canada's telecommunications market plan to prune budgets, he added.
The deepest cut will come from international carriers, which plan to reduce spending by 74 percent from 2002 levels, followed by long-distance and competitive local phone companies, which forecast a 47 percent drop, the study said.
Canada's dominant phone companies, or incumbent local exchange carriers (ILECs), are expected to spend C$4.2 billion on wireline equipment in 2003, making up almost three-quarters of total capital expenditures for the year.
Those companies, including Bell Canada, Telus, Aliant Inc. (Toronto:AIT.TO - News) and Manitoba Telecom Services Inc. (Toronto:MBT.TO - News), plan to spend 9 percent less in 2003 than last year, on average, and they see revenue increasing just 3 percent.
"Despite their aggressive capex reductions, Canada's ILECs have not pruned their capital spending budgets as deeply as their U.S. counterparts, a trend that will continue in 2003," the study said.
The sector's biggest spender, Bell Canada parent BCE Inc. (Toronto:BCE.TO - News), is expected to spend C$2.65 billion on equipment in 2003, a 12 percent drop from 2002. Telus Corp. (Toronto:T.TO - News), the country's second-biggest phone company, has forecast C$1.5 billion in spending, a 12 percent decline.
Budgets for long distance and competitive local exchange carriers are expected to plunge by 50 percent from last year.
That's no surprise given the sector's bloodied landscape, which saw AT&T Canada and Group Telecom fall into bankruptcy protection, while Sprint Canada parent Call-Net Enterprises Inc. (Toronto:FON.TO - News) recapitalized operations, writing off about C$2 billion in debt.
The outlook isn't much rosier for wireless carriers, which forecast a 22 percent spending decline from 2002, despite expectations of double-digit revenue growth.
Spending from once-lavish overseas carriers is seen slowing to a trickle, after Teleglobe and 360networks emerged from bankruptcy protection. The two companies made up 40 percent of total capital spending in 2000.
Cable companies are seen cutting spending to just over C$1 billion from C$1.58 billion in 2002, the study forecast.
post.title: Canada's telecom spending not yet bottomed
